content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?> <metadata> <idinfo> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin> Halley, Robert (retired)  Yates, Kimberly </origin> <pubdate>2004</pubdate> <title>Florida Bay Surface Maps</title> <geoform>maps</geoform> <onlink>http://sofia.usgs.gov/projects/geo_monitor/maps/mps-surfaces/</onlink> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract>The maps show the surface temperatures, salinities, pH, and dissolved oxygen for February and April 2002</abstract> <purpose>The production and transport of biogenic carbonate sediments play a key role in developing mud banks and altering circulation patterns in Florida Bay.  Accurate measurements of sediment accumulation and production rates are required to determine how these processes have changed during the last century in response to anthropogenic influences. Estimates of sediment accumulation rates and annual production rates based on standing crop and turnover of various calcifying species are available from previous research.  Carbonate sedimentation and organic productivity (calcification, photosynthesis, and respiration) are most effectively determined from precise, in situ measurements of alkalinity, pH, temperature, conductivity, and air:sea CO2 and O2 gas fluxes.</purpose> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <mdattim> <sngdate> <caldate>200202</caldate> </sngdate> <sngdate> <caldate>200204</caldate> </sngdate> </mdattim> </timeinfo> <current>ground condition</current> </timeperd> <status> <progress>Complete</progress> <update>None planned</update> </status> <spdom> <bounding> <westbc>-81.3</westbc> <eastbc>-80.1</eastbc> <northbc>25.3</northbc> <southbc>25.6</southbc> </bounding> </spdom> <keywords> <theme> <themekt>none</themekt> <themekey>salinity</themekey> <themekey>temperature</themekey> <themekey>dissolved oxygen</themekey> <themekey>pH</themekey> <themekey>mapping</themekey> <themekey>hydrology</themekey> <themekey>chemistry</themekey> <themekey>geology</themekey> <themekey>geography</themekey> </theme> <theme> <themekt>ISO 19115 Topic Category</themekt> <themekey>environment</themekey> <themekey>imageryBaseMapsEarthCover</themekey> <themekey>oceans</themekey> </theme> </keywords> <accconst>none</accconst> <useconst>The maps have not been reviewed for conformity with U.S. Geological Survey editorial standards</useconst> <ptcontac> <cntinfo> <cntperp> <cntper>Chris DuFore</cntper> <cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey</cntorg> </cntperp> <cntaddr> <addrtype>mailing and physical address</addrtype> <address>600 4th Street South</address> <city>St. Petersburg</city> <state>FL</state> <postal>33701</postal> <country>USA</country> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>727 803-8747 ext. 3041</cntvoice> <cntemail>cdufore@usgs.gov</cntemail> </cntinfo> </ptcontac> <datacred>Data collected by Chris DuFore,  Keith Ludwig, Nancy Dewitt, and B. J. Reynolds of the USGS.  The maps were prepared by Iuri Herzfeld of the USGS.</datacred> <native>Adobe pdf files and JPEG image files</native> </idinfo> <dataqual> <logic>Precise measurements using the same equipment were made at each sampling site</logic> <complete>Value labels shown on the maps depict selected surface measurements for temperature, salinity, pH, and dissolved oxygen along the sampling path.  Each sampling site and time used a different number of data points in preparation of the maps.  See the individual maps for the number of data points.</complete> <posacc> <horizpa> <horizpar>All location data in the study were collected using a Precision Lightweight GPS Receiver (PLGR+96) with precise positioning service (PPS).  The stated accuracy for this device is less than 52 ft (16m).</horizpar> </horizpa> </posacc> <lineage> <procstep> <procdesc>Florida Bay surface temperatures, surface salinities, surface pH, and surface dissolved exygen were measureed as part of the study of sediment transport and its influence on water quality in the Bay</procdesc> <procdate>2002</procdate> <proccont> <cntinfo> <cntperp> <cntper>Chris DuFore</cntper> <cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey</cntorg> </cntperp> <cntaddr> <addrtype>mailing and physical address</addrtype> <address>600 4th Street South</address> <city>St. Petersburg</city> <state>FL</state> <postal>33701</postal> <country>USA</country> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>727 803-8747 ext. 3041</cntvoice> <cntemail>cdufore@usgs.gov</cntemail> </cntinfo> </proccont> </procstep> </lineage> </dataqual> <spdoinfo> <indspref>Florida Bay</indspref> </spdoinfo> <spref> <horizsys> <geograph> <latres>1</latres> <longres>1</longres> <geogunit>Degrees, minutes, and decimal seconds</geogunit> </geograph> <geodetic> <horizdn>North American Datum of 1983</horizdn> <ellips>Geodetic Reference System 80</ellips> <semiaxis>6378137</semiaxis> <denflat>298.257</denflat> </geodetic> </horizsys> </spref> <eainfo> <overview> <eaover>Data shown on the individual maps include salinity (interval 5 ppt), temperature (interval 1 degree C), pH (0.1 change in pH), dissolved oxygen (interval mg/L)</eaover> <eadetcit>USGS personnel</eadetcit> </overview> </eainfo> <distinfo> <distrib> <cntinfo> <cntperp> <cntper>Heather S.
